block.p: Inflation Rate Flat in May, But Up Over Last 12 Months The national inflation rate, which has been inching up this year, leveled off in May, the Labor Department reported.

The Consumer Price Index, the best known measure of American inflation, rose 0.1 percent in May. Measured over 12 months, however, the inflation rate through May was half a percentage point higher than it was last fall. Excluding energy and food prices, the index was up 0.2 percent in May. [Page C14.]

Even in Deal, Seagram Trails S.& P. Since Edgar Bronfman Jr. took control of Seagram nearly six years ago and sought to recast the liquor and beverage giant as a liquor, media and entertainment empire, he has added some value, but Seagram's performance has lagged the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Even if Seagram receives $77 a share in a deal with Vivendi of France, its performance would still trail the S.& P. 500. Market Place. [C14.]

Bear Stearns Net Profit Falls 40% Bear Stearns said that its second-quarter profit fell 40 percent because of a slump in the bond market and a one-time $96 million charge stemming from a federal court judgment. Excluding the charge, profits rose 8 percent and beat Wall Street expectations. Shares of Bear Stearns rose $1.375, to $42.25. [C27.]

Nasdaq Declines in Mixed Trading Stock prices were mixed as the Nasdaq composite index fell 53.65 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,797.41. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 66.11 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,687.95, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.1 points, to 1,470.54. [C12.]

New York Life in Racketeering Suit Top executives of the New York Life Insurance Company were accused in a racketeering lawsuit of enriching themselves by charging tens of millions of dollars in excess fees to the retirement plans that the insurer maintains for its workers and agents. Company officials denied the accusations and said they would prevail in court. [C8.]

Justice Files Brief to Appeals Court The Justice Department filed a brief with a federal appeals court intended to persuade the judges not to begin work on the Microsoft case until the Supreme Court decides whether to take the case or not. [C2.]

Frankel Fights Extradition to U.S. Martin R. Frankel, the businessman accused of looting more than $200 million from insurance companies he acquired, made a concerted effort at a Hamburg courtroom, where he faces German charges of using false passports and evading customs duties on about $5 million worth of diamonds, to avoid extradition to the United States. [C4.]
Bass Is Exiting Brewing Business Bass of Britain agreed to sell its 223-year-old brewing business to Interbrew of Belgium for $2.1 billion. [C4.]

House Passes E-Commerce Bill The House overwhelmingly passed an electronic signature and record-keeping bill that would give new technologies like fingerprint scans the legal weight of ink-and-paper signatures, making it easier for both companies and consumers to do business online. [C10.]

Pondering a Southern Baptist Vote A professor who pioneered the application of economic theory to religion thinks the Southern Baptist Convention's vote to bar women from serving as pastors is part of a rational strategy to maintain distinctiveness and is not necessarily a sign of greater conservatism. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. [C2.]
